overview.short: Yersinia enterocolitica is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rod that commonly causes enterocolitis and mesenteric lymphadenitis.
overview.clinical_context: Associated with gastroenteritis, pseudoappendicitis, and occasional septicemia; often linked to pork products and cold enrichment recovery.

species_markers.notes: Strongly supports Y. enterocolitica versus Y. pestis and many other Enterobacterales.

common_confusions.reason: Shared genus traits and overlapping biochemical profile; both can grow at cold temperatures and are non-lactose fermenters.
Non-lactose fermenting Enterobacterales recovered from stool; requires discrimination with urease/motility temperature profile and selective media.

when_to_question_identification: Urease negativity argues against Y. enterocolitica (consider Y. pestis or Y. pseudotuberculosis depending on other markers).
H2S positivity is inconsistent with Yersinia spp. and suggests Salmonella/Citrobacter.
Strong lactose fermentation suggests other Enterobacterales (e.g., Enterobacter/Klebsiella/Escherichia).

recommended_next_tests.reason: Demonstrates the characteristic temperature-dependent motility profile.
Supports selective recovery of enteropathogenic Yersinia from stool.
